data.title: Don Was’ Pan-Detroit Ensemble leads the holiday weekend music lineup
data.meta_description: If being a Grammy Award-winning producer and record company president wasn't enough, Don Was has rededicated himself to live performance during the past few years. So something like the Pan-Detroit Ensemble was probably inevitable.
data.text:
As if being a Grammy Award-winning producer and record company president (Blue Note) wasn’t enough, Don Was has rededicated himself to live performance during the past couple of years — including membership in Grateful Dead co-founder Bob Weir’s Wolf Bros and touring with Ryan Adams’ Cardinals.

So something like the Pan-Detroit Ensemble was probably inevitable.

The group, which began its first tour earlier this week, including former Was (Not Was) bandmates Luis Resto on keyboards and Dave McMurray on saxophone along with vocalist Steffanie Christi’an, guitarist Wayne Gerard, drummer Jeff Canaday, percussionist Mahindi Masai, Vincent Chandler on trombone and John Douglas on trumpet. The repertoire is diverse — a Was (Not Was)-like blend of jazz, R&B, funk and rock similar to “The Don Was Motor City Playlist” Friday nights on WDET-FM — but Was promises that the delivery will leave no doubt about the band’s musical roots.

“There’s a Detroit ethos in that band,” explains Was (nee Fagenson), 71, who was raised and began his musical career in Oak Park. His long list of credits includes work with Bonnie Raitt, the Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Willie Nelson, Bob Seger, the B-52’s, Barenaked Ladies and many more. “There’s a sound to Detroit music that’s embodied by this particular group of people playing together.

“It’s got a real flavor to it. It’s like a less rigid kind of Was (Not Was) almost. It’s got a groove, but people are stretching out more and hopefully we’re building enough freedom in the arrangements so that every show will have its own character.”

The Pan-Detroit Ensemble grew out of Was booking with the Detroit Symphony’s Paradise Jazz Series that was made some time back, and as he assembled the band Was was so happy with the chemistry that “we booked a whole bunch of dates.” The ensemble will play nine shows through June 2 and is already lining up a fall itinerary. And Was anticipates it will be a going concern amidst his other endeavors.

“I’m gonna do this for a long time, man,” promises Was, who will be returning during July for his annual All-Starr Revue at the Concert of Colors and a fundraising bowling event for WDET. “I love this band. There’s a great energy around it, which is surprising considering no one’s seen a show yet. But tells you how good these players are, y’know?”

Don Was and the Pan-Detroit Ensemble performs at 8 p.m. Friday, May 24 at Orchestra Hall, 3711 Woodward Ave., Detroit. 313-576-5111 or dso.org.

Other music events of note this weekend (all subject to change) include …

FRIDAY, MAY 24

• Veronika Eberle performs Brahms’ Violin Concerto in D Major with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra through Sunday, May 26 at Orchestra Hall, 3711 Woodward Ave., Detroit. Saturday’s concert will be streamed free via the “Live From Orchestra Hall series. 313-576-5111 or dso.org.

• X-Ambassadors welcomes fans to the “Jungle” again at Saint Andrew’s Hall, 431 E. Congress St., Detroit. Doors at 6:30 p.m. 313-961-8961 or saintandrewsdetroit.com.

• The great Detroit jazz troupe Straight Ahead spends the holiday weekend (through Sunday, May 26) at Cliff Bell’s, 2030 Park Ave., Detroit. 313-961-2543 or cliffbells.com.

• The Civic Youth Ensembles’ Civic Jazz Live! orchestra performs at 7 p.m. in The Cube inside the Fisher Music Center, 3711 Woodward Ave., Detroit. 313-576-5111 or dso.org.

• Against Me!’s Laura Jane Grace busts a solo move at El Club, 4114 W. Vernor Highway, Detroit. Doors at 6 p.m. 313-757-7942 or elclubdetroit.com.

• The night after playing at The Ark in Ann Arbor, New York singer-songwriter Ari Hest plays at 8 p.m. at 20 Front Street in Lake Orion. 248-783-7105 or 20frontstreet.com.

• The Loving Touch in Ferndale gets homegrown with Michigan Left, Mushroom Jam and Perfect Strangers. 22634 Woodward Ave. Doors at 7 p.m. 248-820-5596 or thelovingtouchferndale.com.

• Pianist Zen Zadravec plays through Saturday, May 25 at the Dirty Dog Jazz Cafe, 97 Kercheval, Grosse Pointe. 313-882-5399 or dirtydogjazz.com.

• The New Rock Revival features Savage Reaction, Strange Generation, Faded and more at the Token Lounge, 28949 Joy Road, Westland. Doors at 6 p.m. 734-513-5030 or tokenlounge.com.

• Lily Bones, Death Dance and more play in the Pike Room at the Crofoot Complex, 1 S. Saginaw St., Pontiac. Doors at 6 p.m. 248-858-9333 or thecrofoot.com.

• The Brett Lucas Band opens the holiday weekend at 7 p.m. at the Cadieux Cafe, 4300 Cadieux Road, Detroit. 313-882-8560 or cadieuxcafe.com.

• Get the Shot, Life Cycles, Dead Hang, Dead Wrong and Lockdown gang up at 6 p.m. at the Sanctuary Detroit, 2932 Caniff, Hamtramck. 313-462-4117 or sanctuarydetroit.com.

• Ezra Bell, Keyle Brown & the Human Condition and Raynah perform at 8:30 p.m. at the Lager House, 1254 Michigan Ave., Detroit. 313-500-1475 or thelagerhouse.com.

• Ryan Lynch and the Mixed Nations headlines 7 p.m. at the New Dodge Lounge, 8850 Jos Campau, Hamtramck. Dharma and Green Again opens. 313-638-1508 or thenewdodgelounge.com.

• The long-running Detroit Doors tribute lights our fire at 8 p.m. at the Crofoot Ballroom, 1 S. Saginaw St., Pontiac. Doors at 7 p.m. 248-858-9333 or thecrofoot.com.

• Aaron Jonah Lewis’ Ragtime Banjo Revival picks and grins at 8 p.m. at The Ark, 316 S. Main St., Ann Arbor. 734-761-1818 or theark.org.

• “The Beach Boys,” a documentary sanctioned by and with full participation from the band, begins streaming via Disney+. It’s directed by Frank Marshall and Bruce Springsteen’s regular collaborator Thom Zimny.

• The American electronic duo Odesza streams “The Last Goodbye: Cinematic Experience,” a performance and documentary film, with tickets directly via store.odesza.com.

• “Lolla: The Story of Lollapalooza,” a three-part series about the groundbreaking alt-rock tour and festival, is streaming via Paramount+.

• Billy Strings streams live through Saturday, May 25 from Allstate Arena in Rosemont, Illinois, via a subscription to nugs.net.

• The Grateful Dead tribute Dark Star Orchestra streams a weekend of shows through Sunday, May 26 at 2:45 p.m. each day, via a subscription tonugs.net.

SATURDAY, MAY 25

• The Movement Music Festival returns through Monday, May 26 at Detroit’s Hart Plaza, with after-parties at area clubs. For more details, see the story at theoaklandpress.com and visit movementfestival.com.

• E-40, B-Legit, Too Short, Tha Dogg Pound, Mack 10 and more hold a West Coast Takeover at 8 p.m. at the Fox Theatre, 2211 Woodward Ave., Detroit. 313-471-7000 or 313Presents.com.

• Echo & the Bunnymen plays its “Songs to Learn and Sing” at the Fillmore Detroit, 2115 Woodward Ave. Doors at 7 p.m. 313-961-5451 or thefillmoredetroit.com.

• Blues-rock guitar veteran Tab Benoit shreds at 7:30 p.m. at the Token Lounge, 28949 Joy Road, Westland. 734-513-5030 or tokenlounge.com.

• Dad Caps tops a five-band bill at the Pike Room at the Crofoot Complex, 1 S. Saginaw St., Pontiac. Doors at 7 p.m. 248-858-9333 or thecrofoot.com.

• Century Babes joins the Chris Thornburg Apparatus and Vellos at the Loving Touch, 22634 Woodward Ave., Ferndale. Doors at 7 p.m. 248-820-5596 or thelovingtouchferndale.com.

• MC Lars & Schaffer the Darklord throw down at 8 p.m. at the Lager House, 1254 Michigan Ave., Detroit. Shubzilla, Bill Beats and MC Snas also are on the bill. 313-500-1475 or thelagerhouse.com.

• Mouthful of Locusts tops a five-band bill at 6 p.m. at the Sanctuary Detroit, 2932 Caniff, Hamtramck. 313-462-4117 or sanctuarydetroit.com.

• Blood Bell Blues, Guy Snowdon & the Citizens and Redeye Raccoon perform at 8 p.m. at the New Dodge Lounge, 8850 Jos Campau, Hamtramck. 313-638-1508 or thenewdodgelounge.com.

• Kris Kurzawa and Barbara Payton present their tribute to Led Zeppelin at 7 p.m. at the Cadieux Cafe, 4300 Cadieux Road, Detroit. 313-882-8560 or cadieuxcafe.com.

• Lady Gaga’s “Gaga Chromatica Ball” concert special, filmed in September 2022 in Los Angeles, premieres at 8 p.m. on HBO and will stream via Max.

SUNDAY, MAY 26

• The Planet D Nonet plays its monthly matinee at 4 p.m. at the Cadieux Cafe, 4300 Cadieux Road, Detroit. 313-882-8560 or cadieuxcafe.com.

• Heavy rockers Born Of Osiris and Attila preside over a 12-band lineup at the Crofoot Ballroom, 1 S. Saginaw St., Pontiac. Doors at 5 p.m. 248-858-9333 or thecrofoot.com.

• Interference Detroit and Into the Woods LA add to the Movement weekend’s electronic offerings at El Club, 4114 W. Vernor Highway, Detroit. Doors at 8 p.m. 313-757-7942 or elclubdetroit.com.

• Cye Pie, Miss Christyana and Tori Skyy are featured in the Breaking Sound Showcase at 7 p.m. at the New Dodge Lounge, 8850 Jos Campau, Hamtramck. 313-638-1508 or thenewdodgelounge.com.

• Sweden’s theatrical Viking rock outfit Amon Amarth streams live from Anaheim, California, at 12:30 p.m. Tickets via veeps.com.
